titleStmt.title: Proverbs: collection 5 -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

lg.p:
The elephant spoke to himself: There is nothing like me among all the creatures of &C;akkan! The wren (?) answered him: But I, in my own small way, was created just as you were!
1 ms. has instead: The elephant spoke to himself: Among all the creatures of &C;akkan, the one that can defecate like me has yet to be created! The wren (?) answered him: But I, in my own small way, can defecate just as much as you!

You go like an elephant to raise a sunken boat.
1 ms. has instead: An elephant is led to a sunken boat to raise it.
cf. 6.1.03.14 The wild bull is taboo for the plough.

p.q: Like the wild bull, you only do what pleases you.

lg.p: The wild bull wanders about amid the rushes.
The wild bull is free from the plough (?).
The wild bull &X;&X; I abandon the claim.
The wild bull &X;&X; enveloped &X;&X; above &X;&X;.
Wild bull, you &X;&X; your strong limbs.
The wild bull &X;&X; aggressively.
The wild bull &X;&X;.
An ox will catch you in your path.
Like an ox, you do not know how to turn back.
The dog snarls at an ox scrubbed with soap.
The ox has been tamed; its tamers are great.
The ox &X;&X;.
cf. 6.1.02.86, 6.1.26.d6 The furrows seem pleasant to an ox on the threshing floor.
The ox &X;&X;.
The ox &X;&X;
From so many oxen, is there no dung?
If you make the oxen multiply, you may collect their dung.
O ox, you wander about in the street like a commissioner.
The owner of an ox is also happy at being the emissary at the city gate.
The cow jumps to her heart's content, but she does not gore.
O cow, like a cat you walk behind the man carrying the food basket.
No one will give away even a barren cow for nothing.
Like a cow that has not given birth, you are looking for a calf of yours that does not exist!
The cow walks in the marsh, the calf on the dry ground.

A calf entered &X;&X;. It did not know how to get out. When the herdsman came to inspect, he hurled the churn towards it, smashing the churn. When the calf came out, it cowered -- but the churn was still smashed.
Like a horse you paw the ground where you drink.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 287 The horse, after throwing off his rider, said: Were my load to be like this forever, how weak I would become!
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 283 The donkey, after he had thrown off his packs, said: Now I can forget the burdens of former days!
The donkey &X;&X;.
The donkey stumbled, and the dog &X;&X;.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 315 While the donkey was swimming in the river, the dog was busy gathering food: When will he climb out and eat?
He who rents a donkey for a whole year kindles a fire in the moonlight.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 236 Make the donkey sit like this! Make it lift its shrivelled penis!
A donkey is being used to transport one shekel of silver.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 234 Using a donkey in place of sheep will not provide you with an omen.
A donkey &X;&X;: In order to grow powerful, don't let your &X;&X; dwell in the house of your brother-in-law! When you are able to support a &X;&X;, then you may choose a wife.
If you keep beating a donkey on its back, what &X;&X;?
When the donkey, walking in the desert, met &X;&X;, it roused it from where it sat.
A &X;&X; donkey came across a &X;&X; man: Do it and then go!
A sick donkey went up &X;&X;: How long have you not felt well? If until now you have not felt well, &X;&X; there is a canal inspector &X;&X;. Let him come to you, and your bones will feel well again.
The donkey &X;&X; plenty of urine &X;&X;.
A donkey &X;&X;.

cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 212 The lion had caught a helpless she-goat: Let me go! I will give you my fellow ewe in return! If I am to let you go, tell me your name! The she-goat answered the lion: You do not know my name? 'I-am-cleverer-than-you' is my name! When the lion came to the fold, he
1 ms. has instead: the lion cried: I release you! She answered him from the other side: You released me, but were you clever? As for the sheep, none live here!
When the lion came to the sheepfold, there was a dog wearing a leash of spun wool.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 211 When the lion caught a wild boar, he roared: Your flesh has not yet filled my mouth, but your squeals have deafened my ears!
A lion having fallen into a trap, a fox came up to him and said: I'll take your sandals home to the other side for you!
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 208 l. 1 O lion, your allies in the reedbeds are numerous.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 208 l. 2 In the reedbeds the lion does not eat his acquaintance.
The lion &X;&X; the man who &X;&X; said: I shall put in place a house without weapons.
The lion who lives a life of compassion will receive it.
When a lion roars, one says: Don't drop your food!
Is the lion accustomed to eating that which is milled?
Is the lion accustomed to performing the brewers' craft?
If the lion heats the soup, who would say It is no good?
No-one walks for a second time at the place where a lion has eaten a man.
He eats meat in the presence of a lion.

= Alster 1997 5 Vers. A 69
you drink water &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. B 69 Were a lion to approach him, you would chase only the wolf away!
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. A 70 = 5 Vers. B 76 You should not eat the flesh of a wolf. Vers. B adds: Let me subdue it with all my might.
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. B 70 Loving the lion's fish (?), he did not know how to cut it (?).

= Alster 1997 5 Vers. A 71 = 5 Vers. B 74 Nine wolves having caught 10 sheep, there was one too many and they did not know how to share out the portions. A fox came along and said: Let me allocate the portions for you! The nine of you take one sheep. I by myself shall take nine -- this shall be my share!
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. B 71 Imagine a wolf is eating. Utu looks down on it and says: Provided you praise me you will grow fat would be the reply.

= Alster 1997 5 Vers. A 72 The wolf &X;&X; the drain-pipe of a house's roof: Last year we were nauseated (?) by your stench. Now this year we are still nauseated (?)! How much longer will we be cursed with your stench? -- Now, as for me, I am hungry! What can I eat?
= Alster 1997 p. 133 P i 11' A wolf &X;&X; sat &X;&X; a lamb.

= Alster 1997 5 Vers. B 72 While the wolf sat stuck in a trap, he said to Utu: When I come out, let me henceforth eat no more sheep. When I am hungry, the sheep I've taken, whatever you mention -- what will they mean to me? I shall be bound by a righteous oath. -- Now, what can I eat?
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. A 73 = 5 Vers. B 73 The wolf wept before Utu: The animals frisk around together, but I am all alone.
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. A 74 He bites like a dog does when its tetherer &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 5 Vers. B 75 The shepherd cannot increase his flock where the wolf takes sheep.
Dog, you shouldn't &X;&X; bones.
To a dog a dream is a joy.
A dog entered a tavern and said: I can't see a thing. I'll open this one!
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 264 A dog said to his master: If my pleasure is of no importance to you, then my loss should not be either!
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 231 ll. 1-2 The dog does not let me sit down in his master's house.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 231 ll. 3 A rabid dog hates &X;&X; the chain (?) &X;&X;.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 225 The dog understands Take it!, but it does not understand Put it down!

The dog wags his tongue (?) at a millstone
1 ms. has instead: &X;&X; licks his tongue , and says to his companion: 1 ms. adds: It is an omen from heaven! Let me clothe you in the lid of a measuring bowl!
The dog recognises a man who loves him; as the dog is judge, so its tail acts (?) as commissioner!
The dog gnawing on a bone says to his anus: This is going to hurt you!
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 228 A dog which &X;&X; sheep-fat -- dog is indeed its name.
A dog does not stand still on the ferry-boat!
A dog &X;&X;
When the dog goes out into an orchard to get dates, the owner of the orchard chases him away. The thief &X;&X; goes out &X;&X; dates.
A dog &X;&X;
A dog &X;&X;.
A dog &X;&X;
Like a dog, he hates to grovel.
cf. 6.1.03.95 He growls like a dog struck by a ball (?).
Control the dog, but love the puppy!
cf. 6.2.2: MDP 27 102 An angry dog &X;&X;.
To purchase a dog is within your sights; to purchase a waggon is to be destroyed.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 223 A dog which is played with turns into a puppy.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 324 He cried out like a dog in a frenzy; its reward was having its skin flayed.
Like rabid dogs, &X;&X; their paws in the moonlight.
Like a rabid dog &X;&X;.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 309 You behave like a rabid dog stretching his neck into the river (?) &X;&X;.

A dog entered a warehouse. The merchant broke his leg with a wooden door-bolt: Get out of here! The dog questioned his tail: Is there something behind me? Those things which make you happy! it was told. Well then, let me go back again tonight and receive something! And so, upon his return, his leg was again broken. He dragged his tail and sat in the street. A second time he questioned his tail: Did the bolt just come out from in front of you, like before?

The dog &X;&X; winter &X;&X;:
The start of summer will tease my nose!
The dog &X;&X; a yoke does not adorn (?) anything: &X;&X; behind you a fattened ox is being slaughtered.
The dog &X;&X; the shepherd &X;&X; his throat &X;&X;.
cf. 6.2.2: MDP 27 82, 6.2.3: UET 6/2 224 A chained dog starts a fight. Would you not roar at that dog &X;&X;?
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 222 If a dog snarls, throw a morsel into his mouth.
The dog has been taught to pay attention; as long as he pays attention, he may escape his chain.
A dog climbed up onto the roof.
Dog, you are counting sheep.
Like a dog you have nowhere to sleep.
He is a dog without a tail.
&X;&X; they roared at the dog &X;&X; cried out &X;&X;.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 230 ll. 1-2 The dog collects bones.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 230 ll. 3-5 A dog went to a party. When he saw the bones there, he left, saying: Where I am going, I shall get more to eat than this!
When a bitch eats &X;&X; food and drink, the puppies will have no teeth.
When the bitch is weakened from &X;&X;, the puppies will not be able to open their eyes.
Bitches advise their young: You should not eat the food from a funeral offering. When the person has brought it here, they will eat it.
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 232 Like a whelping bitch he bites the workmen.
Like a man's bitch you are walking behind a shaven-headed man.
Like the bitch of a scribe, he struts through the fields as though he were in charge (?).
cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 313 Thus says the bitch to the kid goat: Whether you are yellow or mottled, I still love my little ones.
The bitch is a fool: bread is the food ration for her mouth, and a &X;&X; is the judge for her anus!
When we have a bitch and have caught hold of her, only then will we give her a name.
